question_text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for acute-onset facial dissymmetry. She has no other symptoms. Findings as she attempts to smile are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Bell palsy (Option A), an idiopathic paralysis of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that leads to unilateral paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles, as seen in this patient with a drooping mouth on the right side and unwrinkled forehead. In contrast, upper facial muscles are spared in central facial weakness (stroke, multiple sclerosis) because of their bilateral innervation. Altered taste and hyperacusis also may occur in Bell palsy because of involvement of chorda tympani and stapedius muscles. In classic Bell palsy, initial brain imaging and laboratory testing are not required.
